BUNTES BURANO - Blauer Himmel, bunte Häuser, knifflige Entscheidungen Ein Spaziergang durch Burano, die wohl schönste Insel im Norden Venedigs, wartet auf dich! Du schweifst mit deinem Blick über die typischen, bunten Häuser auf beiden Seiten des Kanals und die liebevollen Dekorationen, mit denen die sie geschmückt sind. Flanierende verweilen immer wieder auf den Straßen und genießen diesen eindrucksvollen Anblick.
Doch auch die bunten Gebäude von Burano brauchen einen frischen Anstrich, um so schön zu bleiben – diese ehrenhafte Aufgabe wurde dir übertragen! Nutze deine Kreativität, um sie zu renovieren und zu dekorieren! Verblüffe Einheimische wie auch Gäste mit deinem Meisterwerk!
Buntes Burano ist ein Familienspiel für 1 bis 4 Personen ab 8 Jahren und ist ursprünglich auf Englisch im Verlag EmperorS4 erschienen. Ihr wetteifert um die vielversprechendsten Hausteile in der zentralen Auslage und die dazu passenden punktgebenden Charaktere, um das Spiel schließlich mit den meisten Punkten zu beenden. Das emsige Bauen endet, sobald jemand in der eigenen Auslage 5 Häuser vervollständigt hat. Bis dahin habt ihr reihum die Wahl, 1 bis 3 Hausteile aus der Auslage zu nehmen oder Geld für das Errichten der eingesammelten Hausteile zu bekommen. Dabei müsst ihr stets die Balance finden wenn es darum geht, ausreichend Geld für den Bau zu haben und attraktive Hausteile zu schnappen, bevor die Konkurrenz es tut.
Buntes Burano ist schnell erklärt, spielt sich flott, fordert aber immer wieder auf erfrischende Art dazu heraus, noch ein paar Punkte mehr als die Mitspielenden aus der eigenen Häuserzeile herauszukitzeln. Dank einer Vielzahl an gibt es in jeder neuen Partie etwas andere Wertungsmöglichkeiten.

boardgame.name: Where Fools Dare to Tread
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Horror and Conspiracy Free-Style Role-Play, where a group of psychic detectives are keeping the world safe from netherlings. Great for Halloween play or for a dedicated group of the truly weird. Play with a neutral Ref. Advancement of levels with Ignoble system of nine tasks. Advantage phase and Responsive phase combat system. Character background generator weaving thirty years of cold war global melt down with conspiracy theory into playable backgrounds for the characters. Quick & Dirty combat for monstrous opponents. Complete rules as published inside Space Gamer magazine in 1993. Very tight system with mechanics designed to make your players fear for the lives of their characters, not through massive damage but by specific vulnerabilities. System of buzzwords become serious penalties but only against certain horrors. The type of demonic host the players face is always uncertain and helps generate a mystery and anxiety inside of play. Best integration of game mechanics into horror ever. Includes the scenario, I Must Die, from the same Space Gamer issue with cover art by John E. Holland.

boardgame.name: EVENT
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

EVENT is a game system designed to collectively manage the actions and interactions of a variable number of characters played by players and / or the master from a given event . The combination of these factors will lead to the natural definition of a story within the context of reference, which is called the setting .

This manual contains the main rules that allow you to start playing. None of these should be intended as mandatory or mandatory and each one of them can be modified or reviewed by mutual agreement between master and players: it is however advisable to play at least one or two games (which we’ll call sessions from now on) with the standard rules in order to fully understand the basic game mechanics.

At the end of each paragraph you’ll find a text box containing a concrete example ( actual play ) of the rule explained above.

In order to play Event you’re going to need a group of friends, a handful of 6-sided dice, some paper sheets and at least one pencil. One of the players, known as the master , will take care of the core elements of the story, while the others, to whom we’ll refer as players , will play the role of a single character apiece.

boardgame.name: Vakantielandenspel: Spanje
boardgame.description:
Name translates to 'Highlights of the Game: Spain', part of a series of such games with different countries being the subject.

This is a game where you can show off your knowledge of Spain by answering questions on History, Art, Culture, Sport and Food.By answering questions correctly, and with a little luck, you will collect souvenirs of the country.

The game consists of 48 question cards, 30 souvenir cards, one round ard, 1 rules card and 1 pamphlet with informative background information about your holiday destination.

On each card there are questions in 5 categories and each is designated with its own icon and colour. The five categories in full are;
Eten en Drinken (Green) - Eating and Drinking
Geschiedenis (Yellow) - History
Sport, Spel en Vakantie (Orange) - Sport, Games and Holidays
Kunst en Cultuur (Red) - Art and Culture
Stad en Land (Blue) - Cities and Countries

On each card the category questions are in a different order. On the back of each card are the answers. You play in rounds. The Round Card is placed on the bottom of the deck. You start with the first question on the card you have just drawn. If the Round Card is on the top of the deck, you put it back on the bottom and then ask the second question, and so on until 6 rounds have been played. On the question cards there are also commands, recognizable because the icon box is blank. These commands are on the lines of "Change a Souvenir to a different colour, Lose a souvenir, and so on.

The Question reader is the player to the left of the player whose turn it is. If the question is answered correctly, the player receives a souvenir in the same category of the question. If the player answers incorrectly then that player must lose a souvenir (if he has one) in that category. The question card is then placed on the bottom of the stack and the turn passes to the next player in a clockwise direction.

Maximum number Souvenirs
The number of souvenirs that a player may have in a category is a a maximum of '2 players - 3', '3 or 4 players - 2'.. If a player gets a question in the category of which he already has reached the maximum, then he can choose a souvenir of any other category if he answers correctly. At the end of your turn you can exchange any 2 matching souvenir cards for one in any other category.

The winner is the first player to get souvenirs in all 5 categories

boardgame.name: Lepanto
boardgame.description:
The table is used as a game board. Both parties begin with their 15 ships on opposite sides on the table (harbors) and try to reach the enemy harbor to land troops. The ships may shell and sink each other. Movement is 4 movement units per turn, while shelling is 6 shots per turn. Shelling is done by snipping plastic discs from the felt pads on the ships. Each class of ships may transport a certain number of troops and can withstand a certain number of hits till it is sunk. Sunk ships are removed from the game.

The first player to land 400 troops at the enemy harbor wins the game.

boardgame.name: Itzamazti
boardgame.description:
The board game Itzamazti, created by Rafael Chávez Rivas, is an abstract game that originates from Mexican cultures, like most of my games, but this time it is based on the god Quetzalcoatl, or feathered serpent god, in its version of two-headed serpent, one of which swallows the sun at nightfall, to take it to the heavens near the moon, and vomit it at dawn by the other head of this serpent, doing with this the cycle of day and night, is a game with simple rules, but very fun.

Rules:
Each player chooses 3 discs of one of 4 colors, and starts in one of the two suns represented at the ends of the board in the languages ​​of the snakes, interspersing these discs with those of another player, from there you must take your chips until the other sun, passing through the moon and avoiding being trapped by another player, because of being caught, you will return so many spaces the opposing player has advanced in his dice throw to catch you, delaying the advance of you, however, once you have managed to take one of your chips to the opposite sun, and with another of your chips you have caught another player, you can add the result in your dice to the points you have obtained according to the position of your chip in the goal sun column, making his opponents go back even more, the first player to get all his chips in the opposite sun wins the game.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Tzintli
boardgame.description:
This board game called Tzintli , created Rafael Chávez Rivas, is an abstract game that originates from Mexican cultures, like most of my games, and is based on the small walls of Tenancingo, State of Mexico , Tzintli means small, the codex that I used in this game tells the story of the towns conquered by Axayácatl, emperor of Tenochtitlan, and the way he used these small walls to defeat his opponents, is a game with simple rules, but illustrative and fun.

Rules:
Each player takes three discs of one color, and 5 discs of black color, each player in turn, places a black disc in an empty space of the board and then one of their own color, placing them alternately on the board until all their chips have been placed , once this is done, the players start by jumping first with a black chip to other tiles, until they reach an empty space, and then in that same turn, jump one of the chips of their own color to other adjacent tiles to an empty space , the purpose is to join your 3 tiles of the same color linearly in horizontal or vertical, and whoever manages to do this first, wins the game.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Metropolys: Character Cards
boardgame.description:
This was an expansion published in Ystari magazine, issue 1.

These cards are randomly distributed at the beginning of the game, face down. They allow players to gain special powers.

Players keep their cards hidden and reveal them when they are used for the first time. Thereafter, they benefit from these powers to the rest of the game.

The characters are:

Entrepreneur: Can match the current bid (for example put a 9 after a 9) at any time.

Investor: Get a Metro token for the majority (and the
associated point). Neighborhoods with a Metro token are considered as adjacent to each other (while they still exist, of course).

Politician: Whenever you receive any -1 tokens, immediately place them back down on neighborhoods (may be different) that already have at least one token. You never take the Archaeological Site card.

Architect: The same-colored neighborhoods on the edge of the city are considered adjacent. "Trendy Neighborhood" tokens are worth 4 points instead of 3.
